document.docTitle: Archimediella abundans Harzhauser & Landau 2019, new comb.
document.masterDocTitle: Turritellidae (Gastropoda) of the Miocene Paratethys Sea with considerations about turritellid genera

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material. The syntypes of Handmann (1882) are lost. Therefore, we designate specimen NHMW 1846/0037/0393 from the Badenian of Steinebrunn ( Austria ) as neotype . This specimen was already illustrated by Hörnes (1855, pl. 43, fig. 13) as
Turritella archimedis
.

Illustrated material. Fig. 7A : NHMW 2018/0307/0001, Fig. 7B : NHMW 2018/0307/0001, both, Coşteiu de Sus ( Romania ); Figs 10C : NHMW 1846/0037/0393, SL: 75.9 mm , MD: 19.0 mm, Steinebrunn ( Austria ), illustrated in Hörnes (1855, pl. 43, fig. 13); Figs 10D
1 –D
2
:NHMW 1871/0010/0382, SL: 66.8 mm , MD: 16.6 mm , Steinebrunn ( Austria ) illustrated in Hörnes (1855, pl. 43, fig. 14); Figs10E
1 –E
2
: NHMW 1869/0019/0204, SL: 48.2 mm , MD: 12.3 mm , Lăpugiu de Sus ( Romania ); Figs 10F
1 –F
2
: NHMW 1963/0518/0000, SL: 39.9 mm , MD: 11.3, Steinebrunn ( Austria ), illustrated in Sieber (1960 , pl. 2, fig. 8).

Revised description. Shell medium-sized, slender, of about 16 teleoconch whorls. Protoconch unknown. Earliest teleoconch whorls with marked keel formed by B spiral cord, followed by onset of initially weaker C spiral cord. Neanic whorls soon bicarinate with two strongly raised sharp spiral keels; B cord usually more prominent resulting in markedly screw-like profile; sutural ramp distinctly concave. Entire shell covered by delicate spiral threads throughout ontogeny. Suture on neanic whorls narrowly incised becoming slightly more pronounced on adult whorls. B and C spiral cords grading into prominent rounded cords on later whorls; t spiral cord may emerge from spiral threads between primaries on 10 th to 12 th teleoconch whorl. Sutural ramp becoming flat to feebly convex usually bearing r and A spiral cords of equal strength or slightly stronger A cord; weak peribasal spiral cord rarely present. Lateral sinus angle moderately steep ranging around 15°, shallow with slight adapical inflection point and a distinct abapical inflection point passing via prosocyrt sinus into weakly opisthocyrt basal sinus; adapical LS p . Base nearly flat with five to six spiral cords with delicate secondary spiral threads. Aperture subcircular, inner lip narrowly reflected, forming narrow umbilical chink; parietal callus thin, narrow. Inner lirae present on late teleoconch whorls, consisting of 7–8 distinct palatal lirae and 1 prominent basal cord in abaxial half.

Shell measurements and ratios . Largest nearly complete specimens: SL = 75.9 mm , MD: 19.0; n = 8 nearly complete specimens: SL: μ = 68.3 mm (σ = 5.5 mm ), MD: μ = 17.2 mm (σ = 1.57 mm ), AA: μ = 17.9° (σ = 1.4°), PA: μ = 12.2° (σ = 0.7°). Lateral sinus (n = 5): LS angle = 15.3° (σ = 1.8°), LS p = 0.85 (σ = 0.1), LS d = 6.3 (σ = 1.5).

The nomenclatural history of this species is complex. Hörnes (1855) identified the middle Miocene specimens from the Vienna Basin as
Turritella archimedis Brongniart, 1823
(see discussion above). When describing coeval faunas from Poland , Wilhelm Friedberg (
1873 – 1941
) recognized that the Paratethyan specimens were not conspecific with Oligocene
Turritella archimedis .
He communicated with the French paleontologist Maurice Cossmann ( 1850–1924 ), who proposed
Turritella erronea
as new name for the Austrian and Polish specimens in a letter, to which Friedberg (1914) referred when formally describing the new species. However, both authors had overlooked that Handmann (1882) had already provided seven variation names for
Turritella archimedis sensu Hörnes (1855)
, including short diagnoses. Four of these are preoccupied, but
Turritella archimedis dissoluta , T. a. abundans
, and T. a. inversa are available names. As first revisers, we chose
Archimediella abundans
as name for the Paratethyan species ( ICZN, 1999 , Art. 24.2.1).

A potential senior synonym of
A. abundans
is
Turritella thetis d’Orbigny (1852)
, which has been used occasionally in the Paratethyan literature (e.g. Kókay 1996 ; Mikuž 1983 ). Grateloup (1846) referred to Brongniart’s species when illustrating specimens from the Aquitaine Basin in his Atlas as
Turritella archimedis
var. A and var. B. He listed Miocene occurrences from Saint-Paul-lès-Dax (early Burdigalian), Saint-Jean-de-Marsac (late Burdigalian) and Saubrigues (Langhian) (ages according to Lozouet 1998 ). D’Orbigny (1852) doubted this identification and introduced
Turritella thetis
as new name for these French specimens referring to the larger spiral cords (‘ les côtes sont plus grosses ’). Thus,
Turritella thetis
was not introduced as a replacement name for the preoccupied
Turritella archimedis Brongniart, 1823
but only as new name for Grateloup’s specimens.
Turritella thetis
, as illustrated by Cossmann & Peyrot (1922) , is undoubtedly closely related to
Archimediella abundans
. A syntype of
Turritella thetis
, from the Burdigalian of Saint-Paul-lès-Dax ( France ), stored in the Muséum National d’Histoire Naturelle in Paris (MNHN.F. A12667 ; https://science.mnhn.fr/institution/mnhn/collection/f/item/a12667?lang=fr_FR) differs from the Paratethyan shells especially in the later onset of the prominent B spiral cord. This pattern is also seen in the Pliocene eastern Atlantic
Turritella gentili Chavan, 1940
(MNHN.F. B38211 ) and
T. lecointrei Brébion, 1967
(MNHN.F. B38446 ) (see https://science.mnhn.fr/institution/mnhn/collection/f/item/b38446?listIndex=118 and https://science.mnhn.fr/institution/mnhn/collection/f/item/b38211 for high resolution pictures).
Landau et al . (2004)
discussed that these Pliocene taxa might represent a genuine Atlantic species (or species flock).
Archimediella thetis
might be ancestral to these species.

Glibert (1962) treated the Paratethyan species as
Turritella subarchimedis d’Orbigny, 1852
and listed
Turritella erronea
(=
Archimediella abundans
) as synonym. This view was surely influenced by the (mis)identification of a turritellid from the Tortonian of Cacela ( Portugal ) as
T. subarchimedis
by
Dollfus et al . (1903
, pl. 29, fig. 10). D’Orbigny (1852) , however introduced
subarchimedis
as replacement name for
Turritella archimedis sensu Dubois de Montpéreux (1831
: pl. 2, figs 21–22), which represents a subjective junior synonym of
Oligodia bicarinata ( Eichwald, 1830 )
.
